application.dc:subject: service-oriented infrastructure

application.dc:description: GRIA is a service-oriented infrastructure (SOI) designed to support B2B collaborations through service provision across organisational boundaries in a secure, interoperable and flexible manner. GRIA's business registry service is part of the Client Management package supporting contextualised service discovery, allowing querying for resources within dynanmic management contexts. The registry allows clients to submit queries such as "Find SLAs for providing Application X where the CPU seconds in the SLA is greater than 1000 and the Usage of the SLA with respect to the used disk space is lower than 500MB". The registry is able to cope with any business context or resource as far as its metadata can be represented in XML. It supports the dynamic addition of new business contexts and new relationships between these contexts.
application.dc:format: Service-oriented contextualised business registry as part of the service-oriented infrastracture GRIA.
application.dev-notes: Supported query languages: XQuery, ooXmlQL (Contextualised query language for service discovery ooXmlQL is automatically translated into XQuery)

application.dc:creator: Jakob Fix, Bureau Veritas (Marine Division)
Bruno Chatel, Chadocs
application.dc:title: dynaprism
application.dc:description:
An online application which gives access to the Bureau Veritas Rules documents. Can be run on a server, locally installed, or off a CD-ROM.
Has Table of Contents, List of Figures, List of Tables.
Supports cross-document links.
Has a quite powerful search facility (thanks to eXist).
All content fragments and all ToC/LoF/LoT fragments are served by eXist.
Serves (static) PDF files for printing. Runs in Internet Explorer or Mozilla Firefox.
Makes rather heavy use of XMLHTTPRequest objects to create rich client.
Has a complex ant-based backend that takes output from FrameMaker+SGML and converts it to XML, and prepares it for import in eXist.
Wants to be a framework rather than a hard-coded application, but so far no time has been found to adapt it to other documents, like the TEI P5.
The code name dynaprism is a contraction of Dyna(Web|Text) and DualPrism (well, who remembers the one or the other?).
The official name is now eRules. There is a world-visible production site and an intranet site with different content.
application.dev-notes: Cocoon sitemaps, Javascript, XSP pages, XSLT styles, XMLHTTPRequest; runs on a server, or from CD-ROM.

application.dc:title: TBRC Digital Library Management System (DLMS)
application.dc:subject: Tibet
Buddhism

application.dc:description: Online reference tool for accessing scanned Tibetan texts and information about the historical, social, cultural geographic and biographic context of the writings. Each text has a bibliographic entry that has been designed specifically for Tibetan bibliography as well as its corresponding MARC/MODS document (when available). To provide deep access to the texts, an outline is created that provides title, authorship, subject and keyword access to individual writings within the texts. There are currently over 6000 volumes online with over 300 outlines (covering approximately 1000 volumes). This represents 4.5 million pages of scanned texts. The total size of the library will be approximately 15,000 volumes and 10 million pages of scanned pages. Knowledge entry is performed using an Eclipse application with EMF generated models of each object/document type.
application.dc:format: eXist running in Apache Tomcat with supporting Java Servlets.
application.dev-notes: XSLT style sheets, CSS presentation, XQuery database interaction, on-the-fly PDF generation and image conversion of scanned Tibetan texts, eXist extensions for translating Wylie Tibetan transliteration to Unicode and Web fonts
